extdescription.message: Save time and effort with Popchrom by creating your own shortcuts for text phrases! Whether it's a simple email signature or several paragraphs of a standard response, you'll love how easy it is to use Popchrom to avoid typing the same thing over and over.

guide.message: Place the cursor before, in or after your abbreviations and hit your defined shortcut (default 'Ctrl + Space') to expand them. You could save your new keys with your 'Ctrl + s' or by hitting the save button. There are some additional parameters, which could be included in your own abbreviations: Current day: %DAY% Current month: %MONTH% Current year: %YEAR% The complete date (today): %DATE% To add days, months or years to the current date: days: %DATE<operator><n>d% month: %DATE<operator><n>m% years: %DATE<operator><n>y% or: %DATE<operator><n>d<n>m<n>y% You have to replace <operator> with + or - and <n> by a number of your choice. Abbreviations with arguments: An expansion may also be an array of two string elements. They are used as the arguments to String.prototype.replace (searchValue, replaceValue) and allow searching for arguments after abbreviations and replacing them inside of the replacement value. e.g. Abbreviation tbug Expand to... ["\s+(\d+)\s+(\w+)", "Hello $$2! Please see http://code.google.com/p/trnsfrmr/issues/detail?id=$$1 for details. "] will allow a boilerplate response with two arguments to expand from tbug 35 joshuato to following personalized reply: Hello joshuato! Please see http://code.google.com/p/trnsfrmr/issues/detail?id=35 for details. Undo of abbreviation expansion: This works by using the shortcut key again, but only when "Select after replace" is checked.
